review.title: Negative-Unlabeled Tensor Factorization for Location Category Inference from Highly Inaccurate Mobility Data
review.abstract: Identifying significant location categories visited by mobile phone users is the key to a variety of applications. This is an extremely challenging task due to the possible deviation between the estimated location coordinate and the actual location, which could be on the order of kilometers. Using the collected location coordinate as the center and its associated location error as the radius, we can draw a location uncertainty circle that may cover multiple location categories, especially in densely populated areas. To estimate the actual location category more precisely, we propose a novel tensor factorization framework, through several key observations including the intrinsic correlations between users, to infer the most likely location categories within the location uncertainty circle. In addition, the proposed algorithm can also predict where users are even when there is no location update. In order to efficiently solve the proposed framework, we propose a parameter-free and scalable optimization algorithm by effectively exploring the sparse and low-rank structure of the tensor. Our empirical studies show that the proposed algorithm is both efficient and effective: it can solve problems with millions of users and billions of location updates, and also provides superior prediction accuracies on real-world location updates and check-in data sets.

metadata.title: Negative-Unlabeled Tensor Factorization for Location Category Inference from Inaccurate Mobility Data

sections.heading: 3 Methodology
sections.text: In this section, we will first briefly discuss how to clean up the raw data for updating the mobility location and generate the categories of candidate locations. Then, we will present our negatively labeled tensor factorization model, followed by a scalable optimization algorithm. Throughout the essay, we will use bold Euler script letters, bold uppercase letters, and bold lowercase letters to mark tensors (e.g. X), matrices (e.g. X), and vectors (e.g. x). The (i, j, k) -th entry of a third-order tensor X and the (i, j) -th entry of a matrix X is denoted by X ijk or Xij.

sections.heading: 3.1 Data Preprocessing and Location Candidate Generation
sections.text: Faced with a collection of mobile location updates in the form of {anonymous user ID, UTC timestamps, estimated location coordinates, location errors}, we first process the raw data. Pre-processing includes three key steps: 1) filtering to maintain only meaningful location updates, 2) linking location updates with category information, and 3) quantifying time in time windows. The details of how this happens depend on the data source used and will be included in the description of the experiments in Section 4.Once the pre-processed location update data is available with N users, T time windows, and C location categories, we construct the possible categories that are set for each user at any time.

sections.heading: 3.3 A Parameter-free Scalable Optimization Algorithm
sections.text: To solve the NUTF model efficiently (1), we assume an alternating minimization problem that fixes one of X and Y iteratively and minimizes it in relation to the other. (1) A nice feature is that the proposed algorithm freely defines the optimization parameters, i.e., the user does not have to fix optimization parameters such as stride length or learning rate.Update X In each iteration of the alternating minimization algorithms, we will first update Y with a fixed X and then update X by fixing Y. Once Y is fixed, our goal becomes a nearest tensor that meets the NU constraints (2). To achieve this goal, we rewrite the objective function (1) by placing the entries within and outside the set, i.e.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In this section we will first perform a simulated study to validate the scalability of the proposed algorithm - it is scalable to large category inference problems. Then we will evaluate the proposed algorithm on several real mobility data sets. All experiments were conducted on a Linux server with an Intel Xeon 2.40 GHz CPU and 64 GB RAM.

sections.heading: 4.1 Synthesized Data Experiments
sections.text: We first conduct experiments with simulated data to verify that the proposed location category algorithm is computationally efficient and resilient to location errors. To this end, we adjust T and C, the number of time frames and the number of location categories to 500 and 200 respectively. We also vary the number of mobile phone users, N, within range {100 K, 200 K, 500 K, 1 M, 2 M, 3 M}, with K and M standing for thousand (s) and million (s) respectively. For a fixed N, we randomly assign all mobile phone users to 10 lifestyle classes, with class memberships being blind to our algorithm. We assume that users of the same lifestyle class visit the same location categories at the same time, while users in different classes behave different behavior. For each user and 20% of randomly sampled time frames, we generate their silent location updates containing 4 location categories.

sections.heading: 4.2 Real-World Location Update Data Experiments
sections.text: Also, the location update data consists of a temporal stream of records in the form of anonymous user data, which we have not fully provided. At this point, we were able to capture a timestamp, estimated location coordinates, location errors, etc., to apply our location categories. - The first step is necessary because we are only interested in places where the user has spent significant time - places that have actually been visited in a meaningful way. - In addition, the dynamics of mobile location updates have not been fully understood. - The frequently used location API on iOS devices, "such as the significant change in the location of the device, such as 500 meters or more."

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: To solve this problem, we propose a novel tensor factorization system NUTF, which is capable of deriving the most likely site categories within the circle of site uncertainty. To this end, we highlight several key observations, including negative unlabeled constraints and user correlations. To efficiently solve the tensor factorization problem, we propose a parameter-free and scalable optimization algorithm by effectively investigating the sparse and low structure of the underlying tensor. Our empirical studies, which have been conducted on multiple synthesized and real data sets, confirm both the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed algorithm.

metadata.abstractText: Identifying significant location categories visited by mobile phone users is the key to a variety of applications. This is an extremely challenging task due to the possible deviation between the estimated location coordinate and the actual location, which could be on the order of kilometers. Using the collected location coordinate as the center and its associated location error as the radius, we can draw a location uncertainty circle that may cover multiple location categories, especially in densely populated areas. To estimate the actual location category more precisely, we propose a novel tensor factorization framework, through several key observations including the intrinsic correlations between users, to infer the most likely location categories within the location uncertainty circle. In addition, the proposed algorithm can also predict where users are even when there is no location update. In order to efficiently solve the proposed framework, we propose a parameter-free and scalable optimization algorithm by effectively exploring the sparse and low-rank structure of the tensor. Our empirical studies show that the proposed algorithm is both efficient and effective: it can solve problems with millions of users and billions of location updates, and also provides superior prediction accuracies on real-world location updates and check-in data sets.
